title: Pop music peaked in 2009
text:
Fight For This Love was the fastest selling song of the year when it came out (Picture: YouTube)

Scientists (me) have done the research (looked at Wikipedia) and confirmed what has long been suspected by millennial pop fans: the genre had its last exciting peak exactly 10 years ago.

Yes, 2009 was the one; the year absolutely rammed with new icons emerging, and existing A-listers churning out some career-best material.

Those halcyon days were now a full decade ago, and anyone looking at the UK’s current No1 (Dance Monkey by Tones and I) in a state of confusion might be feeling a little nostalgic.

See, comparing and contrasting the state of pop now to the state of pop 10 years ago is… well, it’s a little depressing.

Of course trends have come and gone, the way success is measured has changed, and plenty of new, completely different artists have emerged. And while there’s plenty of good stuff on offer now, we really didn’t know how good we had it back then.

Just look at the charts from this exact week in 2009: Cheryl is at the top with Fight For This Love; then the fastest-selling track of the year. The soldier imagery! The choreography! The X Factor performance! Truly a pop culture moment from a star at the height of her powers.

Below her at No2 is Alexandra Burke, Chez’s own former X Factor protegee, with her almighty post-Hallelujah banger Bad Boys; while Whitney Houston’s in the Top 5 for the final time in her lifetime with Million Dollar Bill, and Jay-Z and Alicia Keys’ Empire State Of Mind is becoming a mainstay of the Top 10.

And crikey, there’s so much to come in the weeks that follow, before 2009 becomes 2010. Lady Gaga’s masterpiece Bad Romance will top off her flawless breakthrough year by completing a seven-week journey to No1, Kesha will grace us for the first time with Tik Tok, Miley Cyrus will release her best-loved song in Party In The USA, and Britney Spears will do her bit for threesomes on the absolutely wild 3.

On top of all that, JLS will score their second number one of the year with Everybody In Love, Sugababes’ final line-up will release their first single (About A Girl – underrated to this day!), Jason Derulo will make his UK breakthrough with Whatcha Say, and Rihanna will begin one of her most interesting eras with Russian Roulette.

That number of solid-gold anthems is about equal to the amount we’ve had across the entirety of 2019, but it only covers the last two months of 2009. And there were plenty more across the year before that.

So what’s happened? Has pop died a death since, or have those of us looking forlornly backwards just reached a certain age when the newer stuff doesn’t appeal so much?

Well, I’d say it’s a little of both.

For a start, the world is a hellfire now. In 2009, it… well, it wasn’t a utopia, but lots of us were certainly a great deal more naïve and care-free, and these especially exciting hits were there to soundtrack formative moments in our lives.

Plus, the music back then was just… more inventive. Bolder. After a huge boom in mid-00s indie, pop was resurging in spectacular fashion.

That year had Mariah Carey shading Eminem through the medium of bops (Obsessed? Still a classic), Taylor Swift earning her first British hit, Beyonce continuing her Sasha Fierce era with Halo and Sweet Dreams, and Lily Allen releasing her exceptional It’s Not Me, It’s You album – complete with her best-ever tune, The Fear.

Kelly Clarkson nailed her only UK number one with My Life Would Suck Without You, a strong contender for my all-time favourite song; Girls Aloud released their final pre-hiatus single in the fan-favourite Untouchable; and Paloma Faith, La Roux, Florence + The Machine and Little Boots all made strong arrivals.

Pixie Lott, meanwhile, released a teen-pop debut album I was so shamelessly into that its lyrics inspired about four angsty Facebook statuses a week.

Remember Jordin Sparks’s Battlefield? David Guetta and Kelly Rowland’s When Love Takes Over? Dizzee Rascal’s Bonkers? The Saturdays’ Issues? Agnes’s Release Me? Cascada’s Evacuate The Dancefloor? Two thousand and nine, friends! Two thousand and nine! The list is just endless!

Advertisement

To be clear, it’s not that everything’s dirge now, it’s just that the streaming era has made it less creative, and the charts a bit staler. While it’s true that the genre has always been accused of being cynical and manufactured, it’s hard not to agree at a time when everything feels geared to algorithms and in-house Spotify playlists.

It’s nigh-on impossible now to get new acts on the mainstream radar without either going viral or spending loads of cash on warm-up singles that won’t even chart. And though things have felt a little fresher in 2019 than they did last year, it’s harder than ever to get the good stuff the success it deserves.

Look at Normani’s Motivation, for example, which has done incredibly well to spend 10 weeks in the UK Top 40, but still hasn’t gone any higher than No27.

Lizzo, whose Truth Hurts took two years to get to No1 in the US, still hasn’t hit the Top 10 over here with any song (though, for what it’s worth, that is expected to finally change next week). Unless your surname is Capaldi, Sheeran or Grande, the struggle is real.

At the risk of sounding like a wistful grandad, everything was simpler 10 years ago: more bangers, more boundary-nudging popstars, more all-round innocence. It’s hard to imagine teens now looking back on 2k19 with the same affection – but time, I suppose, will tell.
